Comment: From the article:  >“This legislation will allow today’s kids to be kids again,” Patterson told lawmakers on Tuesday, calling this bill "one of the most important pieces of legislation” he has carried.  I live in Texas where several other persons have complained to me that kids are no longer riding their bikes in their neighborhoods or swimming in local outdoor pools.   Of course, they blame social media.  I tell these fools that increased number of days over 100° means that no sane parent allows their kids to risk heat illnesses for bike riding or swimming.  Sure.  Today's kids are not being kids like my older generation was able to do when we were children.  Banning social media will not magically fix the reasons for this.  That would require Republican idiots like Patterson to understand how Climate Change is impacting even the lifestyles of children.

Comment: I mean, since we're being honest here... it's not everyone else's responsibility to monitor everyone else's kids. Period.      Parents needs to learn about parental controls on the electronic devices, monitor their kids' activities better, and maybe society at large should re-think giving all these very young kids internet connected cameras. That would solve pretty much most of it without having to infringe on everyone else's privacy and rights. Let's not ruin the internet and hold it to some crazy standard because they can't take responsibility for their own kids.
Author: Heximate

Comment: For some kids, the benefits do outweigh the cons.  I highly recommend the book “behind their screens” written by social scientists. A lot of kids don’t benefit and are harmed by it - parents need to talk to their kids more about social media, how to use it, and know about what voices are getting to their kids. Some kids though it provides their only positive social interactions, gives them a support system (which is super important if you don’t have one at home), helps them stay connected to their friends, etc.   Outright banning it is dumb - it’s just as bad as book banning in my opinion. It’s limiting knowledge and experience. Kids will find away around it anyway and they’ll do it with nobody watching so it’s easier for them to view the negative content.

Comment: Well, I like the discussion and will check the book out. Prohibition never did work well in America. Alcohol prohibition was different in so many ways, but the result was criminal enterprises stepping in and of course it was mainly adults involved then, whereas this could mean more criminal group enterprises and  far less regulation for one of the most vulnerable age groups for exploitiation including by perverts.    I am interested in what Australia's experiement will bring though.  Again, a completely different area, but their gun reforms and gun 'prohibition' after the 1996 Port Arthur massacre led to an incredibly safer country, not just for gun homicides but gun suicides.  I don't have the brain power bandwidth to say if it will be a success or disaster in Australia, but I am interested in how it goes to see which it is.
